results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Oh Yeah Wow
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
‘Oh Yeah Wow’ are a Melbourne based creative collective that make music videos, short films and TV programs. In this interview directors Darcy Prendergast, Seamus Spilsbury and Josh Thomas discuss music videos.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.

results.title: Spectacle Talks: Hello Flux Panel Discussion
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
A special panel discussion held at ACMI on 26th September 2013. Exhibition curators Jonathan Wells and Meg Grey Wells joined an extended panel that included Alexei Tylevich (the designer of ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’) and Australian music video directors Darcy Prendergast, Josh Thomas, Luci Schroder and Kris Moyes.
Moderated by ACMI curator Amita Kirpalani, the panel discusses the exhibition, personal experiences in production and the art of the music video. Filmed as part of ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’ 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

results.title: London 1942
results.creator_credit: Peter Tanner, Ken Annakin, Ralph Keene, Verity Films and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: A Picture of Wartime London: “A picture of London in 1942 showing a cheerful though bomb-scarred city. The streets are full of British and Allied servicemen. In the parks there are allotments; tomatoes grow on roof tops. The film shows Londoners in the Home Guard and Civil Defence. It ends with scenes of London after dark.” (Source: Films of Britain - British Council Film Department Catalogue - 1942-1943)

results.title: Glen Keane interview with Emma McRae
results.brief_description: Glen Keane has been with the Walt Disney Studios for over 25 years and is best known for his character animations for feature films such as: ‘The Little Mermaid’, ‘Aladdin’, ‘Beauty and the Beast’, ‘Tarzan’, and ‘Tangled’. In this interview, Emma McRae, ACMI Exhibitions Curator, speaks to Glen about his never-ending passion for drawing and what inspires him to create such unforgettable characters as The Beast and Ariel. Glen also talks about the changes in animation from hand drawn to digital.

Glen also talks about the changes in animation from hand drawn to digital.

results.title: Michael Connor: in conversation with Conrad Bodman
results.brief_description: Michael Connor, Consultant Curator of ‘Screen Worlds: The Story of Film, Television and Digital Culture’, is in conversation with Conrad Bodman, ACMI’s Head of Exhibitions. Connor discusses both the overall concept and the separate sections of the exhibition. Connor and Bodman discuss some of the challenges of choosing, sourcing and exhibiting over a hundred years of creative work and technology relating to the moving image.

results.title: Running to stand still
results.brief_description: Adrian Bush tells the story of how, after spending most of his life on the move, he found friendship and a sense of belonging playing street soccer in Fitzroy, Melbourne, with others from the Big Issue team. Adrian was selected for the Australian street soccer team, which toured internationally, and appeared in an ABC documentary. His experiences with the Big Issue and street soccer have transformed Adrian’s life.

results.title: Home
results.creator_credit: Zephlyn Neilsen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Zephlyn Neilsen reflects on the meaning of home through her recollections of growing up in rural Victoria. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with Arts Victoria and the Community Support Fund.

results.title: A Colour Box
results.brief_description: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement.

constellations_other.name: Circling expanded cinema
constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

results.description: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement, with the addition of a “cheaper parcel post” message. Note: this film has been restored by the National Film and Television Archive (UK) from Lye’s original material using the Eastmancolor process.
description_for_label: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement, with the addition of a “cheaper parcel post” message. Note: this film has been restored by the National Film and Television Archive (UK) from Lye’s original material using the Eastmancolor process.

results.title: The Goddess and the poet
results.creator_credit: David Meagher, Roberto Salvatore and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet Christos Raskatos, old fashioned romantic. Meet him as a poet who has a love affair with words, as a local in love with Lorne and as a guy who catches a crayfish now and then in paradise. Interview taken at Lorne Fisheries, Lorne Pier.
